Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned a lot about adolescents and what make adolescents similar/unique from other people!
I learned a lot about developmental psychology!
A lot about (maybe the entire field of) the neuroscience behind adolescents, legal/judicial issues surrounding adolescents, that the Ventral Striatum/Nucleus Accumbens essentially does everything.
You will learn a lot about the complexities of the human brain during adolescence.
I learned about how the adolescent brain differs from children' and adults' brains and what that means for adolescents in society.
I learned a lot about the adolescent brain in a fun learning environment.
I learned about the adolescent brain and its development/functioning relative to children and adults.
I learned a lot about the human brain, and then specifically a lot of studies about how the adolescent brain works.

This course was an awesome introduction to the world of research in Neuroscience and its application to our daily lives. While this class was focused on the development of the adolescent brain, I learned a lot about how Neuroscience research done and its influence on policy formation and our daily lives.  In addition, I left the class feeling more confident with my ability to read research articles and think critically about said articles.

I gained a basic understanding as to how brain functionality changes across the lifespan, as well as an appreciation for how the developmental trajectories associated with brain development may account for differences in behavior, especially during adolescence, and how these developmental changes are taken into account in therapies and the legal system.
Insights on the adaptiveness of the adolescent brain, and implications of using science to provide resources for healthy development.
I learned a lot about the development of the Adolescent Brain.

I learned a lot about the the changes and developmental patterns that occur during adolescence, the different research methods used to understand and reach these findings, and how such research can be applied practically to laws and clinical treatment. It was very very interesting material.

I learned a lot about development during adolescence! That included how adolescents respond to fear, peers, alcohol, etc. These were very interesting topics to learn about in an academic setting considering how much we talk about adolescents in society as "reckless teenagers" and how there's really a lot more to them!

It helped me to rethink what it means for something to be adaptive, to put results into the environmental context and see the ways that certain seemingly-maladaptive behaviors may be adaptive in differing situations.
I learned about the differences in the adolescent brain compared to adult and child brain. Also, I learned about how knowing about the adolescent brain can be used to change the law.
I learned about the nuances of human brain development and how adolescents behavior differs from adults and childrens.
I learned about developmental neuroscience research on the adolescent brain, how this research can impact policy, and how to interpret new findings on the subject matter.
The course teaches about the development of the adolescent brain, and the social and legal implications of this process.

Strengths:
-very engaging material
-incredible professor 
-not too much weekly work
-exams are short and Professor Casey's reviews are very good at letting you know what will appear on the exams
-the debate is engaging and a lot of fun! 

Weaknesses:
-while the exams generally are pretty easy, each question is worth a lot of points, so if you get two multiple choice or True/False  questions wrong, you are already down to an A- (on the exam). I would rather Professor Casey ask more questions so that each question is worth less.

Strengths: the readings were very concise and helpful in introducing the lecture topics; the lectures were very helpful and engaging 
Weaknesses: N/A

Fun, interesting, applicable, engaging course!! BJ Casey is a fantastic professor who is clearly very passionate about her work and teaching. She makes it easy to do well and really cares more about you understanding the material than trying to trip you up with unnecessarily hard tests.

Strengths: Generally fairly engaging, material is interesting but never challenging (unless you're not a nuero/bio/psych major, but even then it's not bad at all), BJ Casey is a very pleasant professor who is responsive to e-mails and puts on the best review sessions that will (over)prepare you for the in-class exams. The in-class exams are pretty easy too - this was one of the easiest A's I've ever gotten at Yale. Weaknesses: This will vary from person to person, but I didn't enjoy the debate too much. Preparing for it felt pointless, everyone was just memorizing their own parts (and making them as 'amusing' as possible - Professor Casey heavily favors those who make a joke out of the affair) and the grading seemed extremely arbitrary. Also, Professor Casey was gone for quite a lot of the semester (talks in Paris and elsewhere and then illness) and the material covered can be a little narrow-focused and repetitive,. This is fantastic for when exams come around, but the class definitely covers much less material than other similar neuroscience classes.
BJ Casey is an amazing professor! The course is well structured with one midterm and one final, and one in class debate. Super fun!

Strengths: BJ Casey is super knowledgeable, kind, and caring. The course info is always taught with reference to specific studies. Weaknesses: the exams are so short that a few questions wrong means you can lose a bunch of points.

Strengths: Interesting topic, great professor, the perfect amount of work
Weaknesses: None

The lectures were very interesting and informative, although I wish they were less repetitive so we walk away with more knowledge each class (we often began by reviewing the content from the previous lecture and the class always end fifteen minutes early).
Professor Casey made this class a lot of fun. The material was interesting and the way it was presented was wonderful.
Prof. Casey is very kind and really amazing. She does a great job of keeping us engaged, and reviewing the material often. I think we could have maybe covered more material though.

I thorrogly enjoyed the corse. I did not find any weaknesses. The strength of this corse is the professor, BJ Casey and her passion for not only the neurosceince of the adolescent brain but also her students.
A major strength of this course is the way in which it is taught: a rather intimate, thoughtful setting in which questions, collaboration, and creative thinking is greatly encouraged.
Very interesting studies discussed. Class was fun and had interesting activities.
The lectures were very interesting.  I felt like the exams were a bit nit-picky
This was a good and fun class. However, I think the information covered in the second half was pretty dry and simply involved a lot of memorization rather than learning.

This class was amazing! Professor Casey really cared about and knew the material so well and it translated really well in her teaching methods. Lectures were very interesting and Professor Casey always made sure to constantly review what we were learning and make connections between materials. She made class fun and made it a priority that everyone felt comfortable, engaged, and not stressed. I can tell she put it in a lot of effort in this class and it really showed and paid off.

The course was great - the second half of the semester was slower considering how many more classes were dedicated to debate prep so the first half felt a lot more information heavy, but I understand there's not really a way to better balance that.
A great class!
It was a great course and very little homework. I loved the debate part.

I thought the material was presented in a great way and enjoyed coming to class. I think spending so much time on the debate took away some time from learning more material and think it would be beneficial to spend less time on it.

I thought that the exams and the debate were engaging and challenging, although I think I would have benefitted from working on another more hands on assignment in addition, such as a research project, to further understand the material.
I really enjoyed that the course took into account the ethical and societal implications of the science, which I believe more science courses should try to incorporate in their curricula.
If you are looking for a relatively fun and easy PSYC or Neuroscience class, and are interested in adolescents, definitely take this course!
YES! I already have.
Absolutely not! One of the worst classes I have taken while at Yale. Definitely much better courses offered at Yale.

Definitely take this class if you are a Neuroscience or Psych major!! It is super interesting and very applicable (to even my own life since we are all technically adolescents!). You will not regret taking this course.

Overall yes! It's a very low stress Neuro credit that's often fairly interesting and looks at the 'bigger picture' as well. It's very easy to get a good grade if you pay attention in class and put in at least 1-2 days of studying right before. It isn't the most interesting or challenging course, but that was also a positive for me in an otherwise heavy semester. A perfect 5th class!
Yes! Take it for the Science requirement!
Yes, it was very interesting. I learned a lot, and it wasn't too difficult.
I would recommend this course to another student if they are interested in the topic or curious to explore the intersection between scientific research and policy/legal advocacy.

This is a great course to take, even if it does meet at 9 AM. Professor Casey is extremely understanding of the fact that Yalies have a lot of other classes/commitments and will be extremely accommodating as far as workload goes. Plus, the material is really interesting and useful!

I would recommend it if you had background in the class (particularly The Human Brain). For reference, I didn't take The Human Brain, and I think I did fine in the class, it's just that you might feel like other people in the class are more prepared than you are.
Yes! Especially if you are a neuroscience major.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this class to other students. The material was interesting and the class was very engaging, but without an overwhelming workload or amount of stress. Because of this, I greatly enjoyed going to class and it was an overall positive experience in which I learned a lot.
Yes. Interesting subject and great professor. Classes are engaging and you can learn a lot with little effort.
I would absolutely recommend it if someone were looking for a low-stress, fun Neuroscience class.
Yes, absolutely! Amazing class with a small workload but great material. Professor Casey is amazing!
Yes!! SUPER interesting!

This is a wacky course. 

The debate, which is worth a significant portion of the grade, is so bizarre. Truly one of the weirdest experiences I've ever had in a classroom. This is a good science class in that it applies the science to real world through discussion of policy, etc. The content is definitely interesting, but the course structure is frustrating.
Yes! BJ Casey is an amazing professor who really cares about student learning and the material is interesting.

A solid class. If you've already taken a lot of psych/neuro classes, the content might feel a bit repetitive and boring, but BJ Casey is an enthusiastic lecturer who keeps the class entertaining. This class would definitely be good for someone is interested in the intersections of neuroscience and public policy. Workload is very manageable, and there are only 2 exams.  

The class really centers around the debate, where the "arrested" team (the team arguing that changes in the teen brain are maladaptive/deficient) debates the "adaptive" team (the team arguing that changes in the teen brain are advantageous). The debate is fun and informal (for example, some groups did a rap or a skit to illustrate their argument).
YES!
I think the class is interesting and worth taking for all students, even those who arent neuroscience or psych majors.
I would recommend this course to another student because it got me very interested in research related to the adolescent brain and made me want to continue to learn about the field.
I would recommend this to a student who wants to learn about the science of brain development but doesn't want to be required to take various intro-STEM classes to understand course material.
